title.narrative: Urgent Response to the Reception of South Sudanese Refugees in Imvepi, West Nile, Uganda

description.narrative: Based on an analysis of WASH needs, Action Against Hunger proposes to: (1) Improve access of the target population to a sustainable and reliable source of drinking water. Four new water points will be built, one of which will be equipped with a motorized pump. Two pumps with human motility will be rehabilitated and three repaired; (2) Ensure better hygiene and sanitation conditions at the community level. To this end, twenty public latrines equipped with shower space, and twenty latrines adapted for people with reduced mobility will be built to meet the needs of newcomers. In a second step, construction and hygiene kits will be distributed to increase the coverage of private latrines. Hygiene awareness actions will be conducted to ensure the adoption of these latrines and reduce the risk of developing water-borne diseases; (3) Specific action will target malnourished people to limit the impact of water-borne diseases on nutritional status, especially for women and children; and (4) the health and nutrition centers as well as the schools receiving refugees will be supported to adapt their WaSH structures and equipment to the large and rapid increase of the population.

In response to the massive and unprecedented influx of South Sudanese refugees into northern Uganda, Action Against will implement, with the support of the Crisis and Support Center, a project to cover basic needs of newcomers, in Imvepi, in terms of water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH). The deterioration of the political and security situation in South Sudan since July 2016 has led to the massive and unprecedented influx of South Sudanese refugees into Northern Uganda (647,033 South Sudanese refugees between July 2016 and March 2017). Opened in 2017, Imvepi is the last reception area to be created. Located in the Arua district, Imvepi is halfway between Arua and Yumbe, the two major cities in the area. Imvepi is located in a sparsely populated area with little infrastructure and poor soil. It is administered by the Office of the Prime Minister in partnership with UNHCR, with management from the Arua District for access to health and nutrition centers and district public schools.
